surveyResults.justification: I've been growing vegetables with the Dalston Community Gardeners for years now, and we're always short on space. My Turkish peppers and tomatoes need more room than my little patch allows, and I know many neighbors from the Turkish association want to grow their own herbs and vegetables too.

I already work out at home with my adjustable dumbbells, but having proper pull-up bars and resistance equipment nearby would save me having to jerry-rig something in my flat. Plus, after being cramped under floorboards all day doing rewires, I need somewhere to properly stretch out my back.
I'd love to grow my own veg for the weekly boxes I deliver, plus it'd be perfect for the herbs I use in my dinner party recipes - nothing beats fresh rosemary from your own plot.

Would be perfect for gaming meetups outdoors - we could set up portable setups for local tournaments and still have space for the younger kids in the area to play during the day. Plus, benches mean somewhere to sit with my laptop when I need a break from coding indoors.

It'd be like having a free outdoor gallery right on my doorstep - perfect for sketching sessions when I need a break from working in our cramped flat. Plus, maybe they'd let local art students like me exhibit there sometimes.

Working late shifts at the restaurant means I'm always buying overpriced veg from the corner shop at odd hours - having a plot where I could grow my own would save me money and give me something relaxing to do on my days off.

Look, I know Dalston's changed a lot, but there's still tons of young families here and honestly, the closest decent playground is like a 20-minute walk. I see parents dragging their kids to that tiny one by the overground station - it's always packed. Plus, I'd probably end up there myself with my nephew when he visits on weekends.

I'd love to grow my own veg and herbs for the cafe - we're always talking about doing more sustainable stuff at work, and having fresh mint for our teas or tomatoes from just down the road would be amazing. Plus I could finally try that composting system I keep seeing on TikTok.

I'd love having my own little plot to grow things - my flat's too small for proper plants and I'm always buying overpriced herbs from Whole Foods. Plus it'd be brilliant for my art, I've been wanting to do a series of paintings on urban nature and seasonal changes.
I'd love to grow more tomatoes and herbs for the café - my little garden at home isn't big enough for all the fresh ingredients I want to use, and buying them gets expensive.

I volunteer at the historical society on Thursdays, and we've been documenting how Dalston residents used to grow their own veg during the war years. It would be lovely to bring that tradition back - plus I'd finally have somewhere to grow proper tomatoes instead of just herbs on my windowsill.
Would be brilliant to grow my own veg - I'm always cooking Turkish dishes that need fresh herbs and tomatoes, and the ones at the shops here just aren't the same as what my mum grows back home.

I'd love having a plot where I could build raised beds and trellises - been wanting to grow my own veg but my backyard's too shaded. Plus it'd be perfect for teaching the neighborhood kids some basic woodworking when we build the garden structures together.

I'd love having a plot where I could grow veg for Sunday roasts with the family - plus it'd be brilliant for the knitting circle to have somewhere to sit outside in summer while we work on our projects.

I cycle past empty lots every day and it kills me seeing wasted space when I'm paying £8 for a tiny bag of tomatoes at the shops. Plus I've been trying to grow herbs on my windowsill but they keep dying - having actual soil would be brilliant.
I could grow my own materials for natural dyes and maybe even cotton for my DIY fashion projects - plus it'd be perfect for the sustainable fashion content I'm always posting about on TikTok.

I've been squeezing tomatoes and herbs into pots on my tiny patio for years now, and my knees are telling me it's time for proper raised beds. Plus, I could finally grow enough veg to share with the neighbors instead of just boring them with photos of my one prize courgette.

I'd love to grow some Nigerian vegetables like scotch bonnets and bitter leaf - can't find them fresh in the shops around here, and my students would benefit from seeing where food actually comes from during our environmental studies lessons.

I've been growing herbs in pots on my balcony for years, but there's only so much you can do with that space. Having proper allotments would mean I could finally grow the vegetables I'm always buying at the farmers market - and maybe share some fresh produce with my patients who struggle to afford healthy food.

Would be brilliant to grow my own veg - my grocery bills are mental right now and I could use the break from staring at screens all day. Plus I could probably rig up some Arduino sensors to monitor soil moisture for a uni project.

I'd love having a proper patch to grow vegetables - my little balcony garden isn't enough, and with food prices these days, growing our own would help stretch the pension. Plus, I could swap runner beans for Mrs. Patel's tomatoes like we used to do in my mum's day.

I've been tending my small garden for years now, but there's only so much you can grow in a London back garden. Having proper allotment space would mean I could finally grow those heritage tomatoes I've been reading about, and share seeds with the neighbors I meet at the Saturday morning market.
I already get my veg from Ridley Road Market, but having our own growing space would be brilliant - plus it'd give me something proper to do on those Saturday mornings when I'm not volunteering.

I've already got my small patch going at home, but there's never enough space for everything I want to grow - would be brilliant to finally have room for proper asparagus beds and maybe even a small greenhouse plot.

I've got a small garden at home but there's never enough space for everything I want to grow. Having an allotment plot would mean I could finally try growing those heritage tomato varieties I've been reading about in my gardening magazines.

I'd love having a patch to grow my own herbs for the coffee shop - nothing beats fresh mint and basil in specialty drinks, and it'd be brilliant to share tips with neighbors while tending to our plots on weekends.

Look, I know it's not the most exciting option, but finding parking around here is a nightmare. I'm always getting complaints from customers at the workshop about nowhere to park when they drop off their motors. Plus, when I come back from car shows with the trailer, I end up circling for ages trying to find a spot.

I'd love having a plot to grow herbs and flowers for the boutique - we could do little arrangements with locally grown blooms, and maybe even host workshops where customers learn to make their own botanical displays. Plus, I'm always at the markets anyway, so having our own growing space would be brilliant.
I'd love to grow some proper Indian vegetables like karela and methi - can't get them fresh at the shops round here and it'd save me a fortune on my weekly shop.

I'd love to grow my own herbs and maybe some tomatoes - fresh basil would be amazing for the coffee shop, and I'm tired of paying £3 for a tiny packet at Tesco. Plus I could finally try growing those specialty coffee plants I've been reading about in my magazines.

followUpResults.justification: In our community garden in Dalston, we have all different members - some elderly Turkish ladies like me who can't bend so easily, young families with children learning to grow vegetables, and people who want to grow bigger things like courgettes. When I started gardening after retirement, I realized one size doesn't work for everyone.

Look, I'm always doing DIY projects at home anyway, so I'd build some raised beds for the wife's herbs and have ground rows for bigger stuff. Makes sense to have options - same as my toolbox, right tool for the right job.

I love experimenting with different herbs and veggies from my weekly delivery box - having various bed sizes means I can dedicate a small raised section for my kitchen herbs while using ground rows for bigger crops like the heirloom tomatoes I've been wanting to try.

Look, I'm gonna be real - I've never actually gardened in my life. But as someone who spends way too much time optimizing game builds and coding projects, mixed sizes just makes sense. Different plants need different setups, right? It's like how I wouldn't use the same IDE for Python and C++ - you optimize for what you're working with.

In our flat we barely have space for anything, so I'd want different sized plots - maybe a tiny raised bed for herbs my mum uses for cooking, and some ground-level bits for bigger stuff. It's like how I organize my art supplies - different spaces for different projects.

From volunteering at those recycling education workshops, I've seen how different plants need different spaces - plus it'd be perfect for the music education charity to maybe run little gardening sessions where kids can work with plots that match their size.

Look, I spend way too much time hunched over my laptop editing videos - raised beds would save my back when I'm trying to decompress in the garden on weekends. Plus, they'd look way cleaner for any Instagram stories I might post.

We've got this small urban farming project in Dalston I'm involved with, and honestly, different plants need different setups - like the herbs we grow for the café do better in raised beds, but the community veg patch works fine at ground level.

I'd probably experiment with different heights and layouts since I'm always sketching and painting different perspectives anyway - plus my tiny London flat means I'd need to get creative with whatever little garden space I could find, maybe even some vertical bits for herbs.

From running my café and tending my own garden, I know different plants need different conditions - just like how I arrange my herb boxes differently from my tomato patches at home. Some of our older customers at the café struggle with bending down, so having raised sections alongside ground beds would work perfectly for everyone in the community.

At my age, I can't be bending down to ground level anymore - my back reminds me every time I try! The raised beds at the historical society's garden are so much easier for us volunteers to manage, and I've seen how well the herbs and vegetables grow in them.

I spend so much time hunched over my sewing table - having raised beds for herbs means I wouldn't have to bend down as much when I'm picking fresh mint for tea during my teaching breaks. Plus, ground-level rows work better for the bigger vegetables I use in my Turkish cooking.

From all the home improvement projects I've done for folks around the neighborhood, I've learned everyone's got different situations - some have bad backs and need raised beds, others want traditional rows for their corn. Mixed sizes lets people pick what works for their space and abilities.

My nan struggles with her back when she's gardening, and I bet loads of people at the community center have the same issue - raised beds would mean everyone could join in without all that bending and kneeling.

I've been dealing with back pain from hunching over my laptop all day, and raised beds would mean I don't have to crouch down as much when I'm tending to plants. Plus, better drainage is key with how rainy it gets here.

I love the idea of having different sections for different things - like a small raised area for herbs I could use in DIY natural dyes, and bigger ground plots for growing flowers I could dry and use in my art projects. Plus it reminds me of how I organize my fabric scraps - different sizes for different purposes!

After all these years tending my Dalston garden, I've learned you need raised beds for things like herbs and salads - saves my back from all that bending - but ground-level rows work better for my runner beans and potatoes. Can't imagine doing it any other way now.

Been helping with the school garden project at Dalston Comprehensive, and we've learned that different vegetables need different setups - the Year 7s love working with the raised beds for herbs while the older kids manage the ground rows for larger crops.

My back's not getting any younger after 20 years of nursing - bending over ground-level beds after a 12-hour shift at St. Mary's would be torture. Plus, raised beds drain better in London's wet weather, and I can control the soil mix for my herbs and veg.

With my uni schedule and all the coding projects I'm juggling, I'd need different setups - maybe some small raised beds for quick herbs I can grab while cooking, and ground-level for bigger stuff that doesn't need constant attention. Plus, being on a student budget, I could start small and expand as I learn what works.

At my age, all that bending down for ground-level planting would have my back complaining for days - raised beds mean I can tend to things without feeling like I've done ten rounds with a wrestler, just like how I've arranged my sewing table at the perfect height.

My knees aren't what they used to be at my age, and bending down to ground level for weeding and harvesting has become quite the challenge. Plus, raised beds drain better - learned that the hard way when we had that terrible wet spring a few years back and half my tomatoes got root rot.

After all those episodes of Gardeners' World and my Saturday community work at the local allotment, I've seen how different plants need different setups - plus it reminds me of those creative solutions on Grand Designs where they maximise every bit of space.

My back isn't what it used to be at 44, and I've been eyeing those cedar raised bed kits on Amazon. Plus, the Victorian terraces round here in Dalston have terrible clay soil - raised beds would let me bring in decent compost without having to dig down to Australia.
With my bad knees from all those years standing in court, raised beds are a godsend - I can tend my herbs and vegetables without all the bending and kneeling that kills my back these days.

From all the cafes I've worked in, the ones with raised herb gardens out back were so much easier to maintain - I could just grab fresh mint or basil without bending down constantly during busy shifts. Plus, they'd look great in my photography work around the neighborhood.
